1956

LICL Inevoli Os

20 November, 1911,

A 0 8.2 
Mr. S. C. Luk,

te sceT NITO ASS 
224 Norin Meyee St..

AT BLOG 
Angola, Indi 
My dear Ink:

Tank you most heartily for your good letter recently 
received. I am always glad to hear from you. Anything in your 
life or work that you find of special interest will, I am sure,

interest me.

You boys are more than ever on my mind these bays, for 
I can realize that terrible suspense you must be undergoing in View 
of all that is heppening in your own country, so far away. That all 
vill eventually turn out for the best we must believe, China will 
need you boys more than ever in view of the changes that have taken 
place, and I am sure that you will all nequit yourselves creäitably 
in bringing about a new ani permanent order of things. I most sin -
cerely hope that you will not much longer be kept in suspense, but 
that you will receive some definite wora from those who are dearest 
to you, and will lear that all is well with them. Don't get dis -
couraged and disheartened. Every one of us has to pass through tryk 
ing ordeals at times in our lives, and only as we lece these trials 
resolutely and courageously do we prove ourselves reol men.

My best wishes to you, as always,

metadata.name: Phillips Academy
metadata.abstract: Letter expressing support to Luk and the hope that he will hear from his dearest ones soon and that the suspense will end soon. Stearns says not to be disheartened, and that trials such as these should be faced squarely.
metadata.collection: Head of School (Stearns) correspondence with Chinese alumni
